— GINNIS

CLIFF HARDING (47), Hopkins tailback, gallops for a substantial gain on an end run on
the Blue Jay touchdown drive as the Jays defeat Western Maryland, 7-0. The victory enabled the
Jays to capture their first Mason-Dixon title since 1948. The victory also marked the first time since
1922-1923 that the Birds have been able to defeat their arch-rivals in successive seasons.

a long time," the DSRC has not
been able to consider many futUre
plans, said the president, but it
is now handling the "big job of
organization according to the
constitution, setting up house
committees, especially."
The house committees will consist of the DSRC representative
from each entry and two assistants one from each floor other
than the one representative lives
on, appointed by him with the
consent of the members of the
floor they shall represent. The
function of the house committees
will be to work more closely with
students in improving dormitory
living. Hutchings added, "I'd like
to get more ideas from the whole
dorm, rather than just from the
Council itself."
Hutchings noted that House B
had established quiet hours beginning at seven every Sunday
evening through Friday, and said,
"I think the other entries should
get together to make a gentleman's agreement to be quiet
also," although he added that the
dorms are "better as far as noise
is concerned" this year as compared to last year.

Develop & Extend
Your Capabilities

—At APL Where a Unique Combination of Industrial
and Academic Approaches is Applied to R & D Problems

The Applied Physics Laboratory
(APL)of The Johns Hopkins University, one of the country's leading R & D organizations, affords
young men of above-average skill
and originality unusual opportunities for rapid progress toward (1)
professional specialization, or (2)
technical administration or operations.
APL is unique in that it is
neither an industrial nor an, academic organization. Instead it is a
composite of both, having drawn
freely from the methodologies of
each. Because of this, APL has
'managed to keep in the vanguard,
having pioneered the proximity
fuze, the first supersonic ramjet
engine,and the missiles TERRIER,
TALOS and TARTAR. APL has
sole responsibility for the Navy's
Bumblebee guided. missile program, directs the work of 21

associate and sub-contractors,
among them leading universities
and industrial organizations.
Location & Facilities

As a result its staff members
enjoy an interchange of ideas with
members of these various organizations; have access to their facili'ties, in addition to the wealth of
equipment available at APL's
350,000 sq. ft. laboratories midway between Washington, D. C.
and Baltimore, and in Silver
Spring, Md. In this environment
men of originality and talent
flourisb. Salaries compare favorably with those of other R & D
organizations; staff benefits are
manifold, including a strong program of financial assistance for
graduate work. For full information contact your Placement Officer or write: Professional Staff

Metallurgical Instrumentation

Automatic control, or automation, or data reduction are
all Instrumentation, and offer some of the broadest and most
satisfying careers available to today's engineers and scientists.,
Atomic energy, iron and steel, aircraft and automobiles,
chemicals and chinaware, petroleum and electric power are
only a few of the many industries which need instruments.
This need creates permanent opportunities in many of our operations, including research and development, product engineering, industrial engineering, production, inspection, market development and customer contacts.
The products with which you would be concerned include
automatic, high-precision instruments for controlling, recording and indicating temperature, chemical concentration, radiation phenomena, frequency and load and many other conditions. For heat-treaters we make furnaces and process
equipment. For the worker in science—whether student or
researcher—we make both automatic and manual laboratorytype instruments, with which you may already be familiar. 4(
P- The Company has about 3000 people—is one of the biggest
in its field, yet is compact enough for you to be able to "follow
the score." Its reputation for progressiveness in industrial
relations, and for quality of product is world wide.
Wayne L. Besselman, our Coordinator of Technical Employment, will be on the campus on December 7, 1956 with
information which he will cordially share about our very
modern opportunities and rewards for engineers and scientists.
Your placement bureau will arrange an appointment with Mr.
Besselman, at your request.

NEWS -LETTER

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOV. 30, 1956

Bernstein Tops Scorers;
Jay Booters Finish 4-4-1
in the past 6 years."

By JIM CtoRKRAN

1

The sophomore-ladened varsity soccer squad finished the
1956 season with a 4-4-1 record.
The pitchmen registered wins
over Bucknell, Loyola, Delaware
and Western Maryland; while
losing to Drexel, Towson State
Teachers, University of Maryland
and Washington College. A tie
With Gettysburg was the lone
Mark in the deadlock column.
Leading the list of scorers for
the Jays was Ed Bernstein with
8 goals, followed by Bob Tebo
Who registered 4 markers, and
Manuel Gracia who netted two
goals. Bruce Duffany, Gerry
Bartell, Bob McDonald, and Captain George Whitlock each registered a single tally.

Jays Spoil Terrors
The Jay pitchmen, after opening the season with a vastly inexperienced team due to the
abundance of sophomores, won
4 out of their last six games,
including a win over favored
Western Maryland that spoiled
the Green Terrors chances of a
tie for the championship.
Coach
Williamson
further
imcommented, "Everybody
proved so much that it would be
hard to single out any individuals. I am very pleased that we
had a successful season and I
am looking forward to next year
since almost the entire squad will
be returning."

Captain Injured
George Whitlock, team captain, suffered an ankle injury
early in the season and missed
the last five games. George is a
senior and will be replaced next
Year by co-captains Bruce DuffanY and Ed Bernstein, who were
recently chosen to fill the cocaptain positions.
. Commelling on the team play
during his first year as varsity
coach, Gerry Williamson states,
"I ani pleased with the cooperation, spirit, and hustle that prevailed throughout the season.
The team improved during the
course of the season more than
any team has done at Hopkins

Frosh B-Ballers
To Open Season
On December 15
Greeted by 30 freshmen last
Tuesday, Coach Robert Scott initiated workouts in preparation
for the Jay Frosh basketball
opener with Baltimore Junior
College which is slated for December 15.
Scott conducted tryouts from
November 26 to 28 in order to
test the capabilities of the squad.
A squad cut was slated for the
purpose of giving the coach a
more workable squad.
According to Scott, in early
practice sessions ;..arry Becker,
former Forest Park eager, Pete
Doyle of Hamburg, N.Y., Bill
Devo of Bradford, Pa., and Larry
Fesser of Taneytown, Md.,
showed considerable, promise.
Other Frosh who rated plaudits
from the Frosh cage tutor were
Larry Naughton of Greenville,
N.Y., Joe Ranelli of Denver,
Mass., and Shelly P. Wollman
of Annapolis High School.

In the BIA's Independent
football league, the 69'ers downed
the Veterans Club by a 26-4
score as Bruce Lynn passed for
four touchdowns. The Newman
Club bowed to the Rowland
The Jays will open the 1956Ghosts by a 22-8 score in other 57 campaign on December 15 on

year the Jays compiled a 9-4 log.

Varsity Grapplers Strive
To Improve On Last Year
Striving to improve last years'
record of one win and five losses,
the varsity wrestling squad is
working out daily under the direction of Coach Wilson Fewster
in preparation for their opening
match with Western Maryland
on December 14 at Homewood.
Coach Fewster stated, "We
should have a better seasonal
record than last year, but we are
still looking for help in the lower
weight classes."
The Jay grapplers have five
lettermen returning from last
season, including Sam Wright,
Mason-Dixon heavyweight
champion. Wright and Frank
Young, 130 pound matman, have
been elected to the co-captain
posts.
Bob Patridge, 147 pounder,
Mike McLaughlin and Mel Alexanderwicz, 157 pound class candidate, are the other returning

monogram winners. Owen Sear,
who was on the squad last season
but did not receive a letter,
rounds out the returnees.
According to Fewster, the Jay
squad includes several promising
sophomores. Bob Sanford, who
wrestled at Baltimore Poly, is
vying for either the 130 or 137
pound post. Macy Darling, who
Fewster expects to develop into
a fine matman, Art Resnick, Jim
Tress, and Al Plishker are newcomers to the Jay squad.
With only a few days of practice, Coach Fewster said it was
too early to be sure about the
chances of the team, but, said
that the Jays are weak in the
lighter weights and strong in the
heavyweight with Sam Wright.
"If wrestling paid off on willingness, we'd win, but it all depends on skill," Fewster concluth
ed.

Should certainly go to all the

To The Editors
Of The News-Letter:
In the November 16 of the
News-Letter you seriously misrepresented a few informal comments which Dr. Eisenhower
made during a purely social visit
to a fraternity house.
His views on the graduate an
undergraduate programs of the
university were candidly set forth
in his press conference at Johns
Hopkins on October 1 and his
talk at Shriver Hall on October
19. In his documented public
statements and his private conversations with faculty and students, he has repeatedly made his
position clear. I would summarize his views and position this
way:
The Johns Hopkin,s University
has always been and must always
be a great graduate institution,
small in size, supreme in quality
—a university in which eminent
faculty scholars and students of
inquiring mind, associated in the
stimulating atmosphere of freedom, seek the truth and enrich
our society with their findings
and interpretations.
Johns Hopkins has also always
had and must always have a
strong undergraduate program,
small in size, high in quality—a
program that attracts young men
of high intellectual ability, character, and leadership potential.
He has said that he believes
both the graduate and underbe
programs can
graduate
strengthened and that later he
will specify steps he believes are
essential to accomplish this desirable end.
Lynn Poole
Director of Public Relations

the Blue Jay touchdown drive as the Jays defeat Western Maryland, 7-0. The victory enabled the

—At APL Where a Unique Combination of Industrial
and Academic Approaches is Applied to R & D Problems

The Applied Physics Laboratory
(APL)of The Johns Hopkins University, one of the country's leading R & D organizations, affords
young men of above-average skill
and originality unusual opportunities for rapid progress toward (1)
professional specialization, or (2)
technical administration or operations.
APL is unique in that it is
neither an industrial nor an, academic organization. Instead it is a
composite of both, having drawn
freely from the methodologies of
each. Because of this, APL has
'managed to keep in the vanguard,
having pioneered the proximity
fuze, the first supersonic ramjet
engine,and the missiles TERRIER,
TALOS and TARTAR. APL has
sole responsibility for the Navy's
Bumblebee guided. missile program, directs the work of 21

associate and sub-contractors,
among them leading universities
and industrial organizations.
Location & Facilities

As a result its staff members
enjoy an interchange of ideas with
members of these various organizations; have access to their facili'ties, in addition to the wealth of
equipment available at APL's
350,000 sq. ft. laboratories midway between Washington, D. C.
and Baltimore, and in Silver
Spring, Md. In this environment
men of originality and talent

Automatic control, or automation, or data reduction are
all Instrumentation, and offer some of the broadest and most

Atomic energy, iron and steel, aircraft and automobiles,

automatic, high-precision instruments for controlling, recording and indicating temperature, chemical concentration, radiation phenomena, frequency and load and many other conditions. For heat-treaters we make furnaces and process

and Washington College. A tie

Mark in the deadlock column.

8 goals, followed by Bob Tebo

Varsity Grapplers Strive
To Improve On Last Year
Striving to improve last years'
record of one win and five losses,
the varsity wrestling squad is
working out daily under the direction of Coach Wilson Fewster
in preparation for their opening
match with Western Maryland
on December 14 at Homewood.
Coach Fewster stated, "We
should have a better seasonal
record than last year, but we are
still looking for help in the lower
weight classes."
The Jay grapplers have five
lettermen returning from last
season, including Sam Wright,
Mason-Dixon heavyweight
champion. Wright and Frank
Young, 130 pound matman, have
been elected to the co-captain
posts.
Bob Patridge, 147 pounder,
Mike McLaughlin and Mel Alexanderwicz, 157 pound class candidate, are the other returning

monogram winners. Owen Sear,
who was on the squad last season
but did not receive a letter,
rounds out the returnees.
According to Fewster, the Jay
squad includes several promising
sophomores. Bob Sanford, who
wrestled at Baltimore Poly, is
vying for either the 130 or 137
pound post. Macy Darling, who
Fewster expects to develop into
a fine matman, Art Resnick, Jim
Tress, and Al Plishker are newcomers to the Jay squad.
With only a few days of practice, Coach Fewster said it was
too early to be sure about the
chances of the team, but, said
that the Jays are weak in the
lighter weights and strong in the
heavyweight with Sam Wright.
"If wrestling paid off on willingness, we'd win, but it all depends on skill," Fewster concluth
ed.

To The Editors
Of The News-Letter:
In the November 16 of the
News-Letter you seriously misrepresented a few informal comments which Dr. Eisenhower
made during a purely social visit
to a fraternity house.
His views on the graduate an
undergraduate programs of the
university were candidly set forth
in his press conference at Johns
Hopkins on October 1 and his
talk at Shriver Hall on October
19. In his documented public
statements and his private conversations with faculty and students, he has repeatedly made his
position clear. I would summarize his views and position this
way:
The Johns Hopkin,s University
has always been and must always
be a great graduate institution,
small in size, supreme in quality
—a university in which eminent
faculty scholars and students of
inquiring mind, associated in the
stimulating atmosphere of freedom, seek the truth and enrich
our society with their findings
and interpretations.
Johns Hopkins has also always
had and must always have a
strong undergraduate program,
small in size, high in quality—a
program that attracts young men
of high intellectual ability, character, and leadership potential.
He has said that he believes
both the graduate and underbe
programs can
graduate
strengthened and that later he
will specify steps he believes are
essential to accomplish this desirable end.
Lynn Poole
Director of Public Relations
